articles.headline: Mourning a Boy, Crowds in Syria Defy Crackdown
articles.snippet: The crowds protesting the authoritarian rule of President Bashar al-Assad appeared fueled in part by anger about the torture and killing of a 13-year-old boy.
articles.abstract: The crowds protesting the authoritarian rule of President Bashar al-Assad appeared fueled in part by anger about the torture and killing of a 13-year-old boy.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Syrians poured into the streets on Friday in some of the largest antigovernment protests yet despite the shutdown of much of Syria’s Internet network, which has been crucial to demonstrators’ ability to mobilize and a major source of information for those outside the country.
articles.byline: By Liam Stack and Katherine Zoepf

articles.headline: Revealing Excessive 401(k) Fees
articles.snippet: Even though the Labor Department has approved new rules for fee disclosure for retirement plans, to go into effect next year, consumers should investigate the often-hidden costs of their own plans.
articles.abstract: Even though the Labor Department has approved new rules for fee disclosure for retirement plans, to go into effect next year, consumers should investigate the often-hidden costs of their own plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: You may not realize this, but your 401(k) or other workplace retirement plan is not free.

articles.headline: Murano Pursues a Renaissance
articles.snippet: New hotels reflect a radical change in the self-image of an island whose history has been inextricably linked with glassmaking since 1291.
articles.abstract: New hotels reflect a radical change in the self-image of an island whose history has been inextricably linked with glassmaking since 1291.
articles.lead_paragraph: MURANO, Italy — The quasi-monastic quiet of this lagoon island a short vaporetto ride from Venice has been broken intermittently in recent months by ear-splitting saws and the low grumble of heavy machinery.

articles.headline: A Stream of Postcards, Shot by Phone
articles.snippet: Instagram and other mobile photo-sharing applications are attracting investors and millions of users.
articles.abstract: Instagram and other mobile photo-sharing applications are attracting investors and millions of users.
articles.lead_paragraph: Digital camera sales may be weak, but thanks to cellphones, picture-taking has never been more of an everyday thing. Now a wave of mobile applications is letting people tweak their cellphone snapshots and share them with friends and strangers.

articles.headline: War of Ideas on U.S. Budget Overshadows Job Struggle
articles.snippet: A run of disappointing economic data is emboldening Congressional Republicans in their standoff with the White House over the best way to encourage growth.
articles.abstract: A run of disappointing economic data is emboldening Congressional Republicans in their standoff with the White House over the best way to encourage growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A run of disappointing economic data, punctuated by Friday’s employment numbers, is emboldening Congressional Republicans in their standoff with the White House over the best way for the government to encourage growth.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Stolen Data Is Tracked to Hacking at Lockheed
articles.snippet: Lockheed’s finding heightened concerns that other companies or government agencies that use SecurID tokens could be vulnerable.
articles.abstract: Lockheed’s finding heightened concerns that other companies or government agencies that use SecurID tokens could be vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lockheed Martin said Friday that it had proof that hackers breached its network two weeks ago partly by using data stolen from a vendor that supplies coded security tokens to tens of millions of computer users.

articles.headline: Where Prisoners Can Do Anything, Except Leave
articles.snippet: Carrying assault rifles and sipping whiskey poolside, inmates at Venezuela’s San Antonio prison serve amid a surreal mix of hedonism and force.
articles.abstract: Carrying assault rifles and sipping whiskey poolside, inmates at Venezuela’s San Antonio prison serve amid a surreal mix of hedonism and force.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORLAMAR, Venezuela — On the outside, the San Antonio prison on Margarita Island looks like any other Venezuelan penitentiary. Soldiers in green fatigues stand at its gates. Sharpshooters squint from watchtowers. Guards cast menacing glances at visitors before searching them at the entrance.

articles.headline: Obama Retools 2008 Machine for Tough Run
articles.snippet: President Obama is hoping his campaign machinery can overcome high unemployment and a fractured coalition.
articles.abstract: President Obama is hoping his campaign machinery can overcome high unemployment and a fractured coalition.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Saddled with a faltering economic recovery, President Obama is rebuilding the campaign machinery that vaulted him into office, hoping it can overcome the challenges of persistently high unemployment and a fractured coalition of supporters.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Citing Medical Needs, Yemeni Leader Goes to Saudi Arabia
articles.snippet: President Ali Abdullah Saleh left for treatment a day after being wounded in an attack, Saudi officials said. News reports point to the vice president as Yemen’s acting leader.
articles.abstract: President Ali Abdullah Saleh left for treatment a day after being wounded in an attack, Saudi officials said. News reports point to the vice president as Yemen’s acting leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Yemen’s embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, arrived in Saudi Arabia on Saturday for urgent medical treatment of wounds sustained in a bold attack on the presidential compound, Saudi officials said, abruptly shifting the political calculus that has allowed him to cling to power despite months of protest and violence.

articles.headline: Drug Makers’ Feared Enemy Switches Sides, as Their Lawyer
articles.snippet: Michael K. Loucks, arguably the nation’s most influential prosecutor of health care fraud, has emerged in recent months as zealous a corporate defender as he was a prosecutor.
articles.abstract: Michael K. Loucks, arguably the nation’s most influential prosecutor of health care fraud, has emerged in recent months as zealous a corporate defender as he was a prosecutor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael K. Loucks was arguably the nation’s most influential prosecutor of health care fraud.

articles.headline: Inciting a Revolution: The Investor Spring
articles.snippet: Disgruntled shareholders of Celgene Corporation have used the Web to rally holders of 2.7 million shares to vote against the company’s pay practices.
articles.abstract: Disgruntled shareholders of Celgene Corporation have used the Web to rally holders of 2.7 million shares to vote against the company’s pay practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE Arab Spring gave Joseph W. O’Donnell an idea about, of all things, his investments.

articles.headline: As Iraqi Militants Flee, Families Are Targets of Blood Reckoning
articles.snippet: Tribal leaders say that scores of family members of insurgents have been attacked and killed in recent years as Iraqis turned against Al Qaeda and other militant groups.
articles.abstract: Tribal leaders say that scores of family members of insurgents have been attacked and killed in recent years as Iraqis turned against Al Qaeda and other militant groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIRKUK, Iraq — Even his parents admit that Faras Awad was a killer. As an insurgent leader in this northern Iraqi city, he kidnapped women and executed civilians in the years after the American invasion. Then he vanished, to escape the law, his enemies and a $50,000 bounty on his head.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Omar Al-Jawoshy

articles.headline: ‘For the Dogs’ Has a Whole New Meaning
articles.snippet: The pet industry has proved remarkably resilient to the downturn, as humans buy gourmet meals and bottled water for dogs.
articles.abstract: The pet industry has proved remarkably resilient to the downturn, as humans buy gourmet meals and bottled water for dogs.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla.

articles.headline: For the Jobless, Little U.S. Help on Foreclosure
articles.snippet: Programs already plagued by delays and poor participation were not designed to fully address unemployment, now the primary cause of foreclosures.
articles.abstract: Programs already plagued by delays and poor participation were not designed to fully address unemployment, now the primary cause of foreclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s main program to keep distressed homeowners from falling into foreclosure has been aimed at those who took out subprime loans or other risky mortgages during the heady days of the housing boom. But these days, the primary cause of foreclosures is unemployment.

articles.headline: Protesters in Yemen Rejoice as Leader Goes to Saudi Arabia
articles.snippet: Yemenis celebrated after the embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, went to Saudi Arabia for urgent medical treatment.
articles.abstract: Yemenis celebrated after the embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, went to Saudi Arabia for urgent medical treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Thousands of antigovernment protesters celebrated in the streets of Yemen’s capital on Sunday, setting off fireworks and slaughtering cows to mark the departure of President Ali Abdullah Saleh for medical treatment, despite new uncertainty about when — and even whether — he would agree to a lasting transfer of power.

articles.headline: Israeli Soldiers Shoot at Protesters on Syrian Border
articles.snippet: Israeli forces fired at protesters on the Syrian frontier after protesters tried to breach the border for the second time in three weeks. A Syrian news agency reported 22 killed.
articles.abstract: Israeli forces fired at protesters on the Syrian frontier after protesters tried to breach the border for the second time in three weeks. A Syrian news agency reported 22 killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli forces fired at pro-Palestinian protesters on the Syrian frontier on Sunday as they tried to breach the border for the second time in three weeks, reflecting a new mode of popular struggle and deadly confrontation fueled by turmoil in the Arab world and the vacuum of stalled peace talks.

articles.headline: Steeper Pullout Is Raised as Option for Afghanistan
articles.snippet: President Obama’s national security team is pondering greater troop reductions, with some officials saying the rising cost of the war and the death of Osama bin Laden justify a change.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s national security team is pondering greater troop reductions, with some officials saying the rising cost of the war and the death of Osama bin Laden justify a change.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s national security team is contemplating troop reductions in Afghanistan that would be steeper than those discussed even a few weeks ago, with some officials arguing that such a change is justified by the rising cost of the war and the death of Osama bin Laden, which they called new “strategic considerations.”
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: For Couric, ABC’s Pitch Proved Best
articles.snippet: ABC announced that it has signed Katie Couric to a multiyear contract to host a new daytime talk show, and she will also join the ABC News division.
articles.abstract: ABC announced that it has signed Katie Couric to a multiyear contract to host a new daytime talk show, and she will also join the ABC News division.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Feb. 8, executives from NBC, including Steve Burke, the new chief executive, and Steve Capus, the president of news, made their way to the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan, prepared to make a pitch to bring their one-time news star, Katie Couric, back into the network fold.

articles.headline: Data Grows, and So Do Storage Sites
articles.snippet: New investment is driving a boomlet in the niche business of online storage, adding to an already lengthy list of competitors.
articles.abstract: New investment is driving a boomlet in the niche business of online storage, adding to an already lengthy list of competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When people had only one or two computers, file sharing wasn’t a big worry.

articles.headline: Online Video Start-Ups Seek to Carve Out a Place Beside YouTube
articles.snippet: “People may still scoff at online video, but this is a real business now,” said Mike Michaud, co-owner of Channel Awesome.
articles.abstract: “People may still scoff at online video, but this is a real business now,” said Mike Michaud, co-owner of Channel Awesome.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For many Internet users, YouTube is synonymous with online video. But Mike Michaud and several friends who live in suburban Chicago are trying to change that.

articles.headline: Uneven Growth for Film Studio With a Message
articles.snippet: Participant Media, the film industry’s most visible attempt at social entrepreneurship, turned seven this year, and its success has been uneven.
articles.abstract: Participant Media, the film industry’s most visible attempt at social entrepreneurship, turned seven this year, and its success has been uneven.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Doing well is difficult. So is doing good.

articles.headline: Bank Shares Take a Beating, and It May Not Be Over Yet
articles.snippet: Giants like Goldman Sachs and Bank of America are trading at well below the valuation of other large companies, but even bargain hunters are wary.
articles.abstract: Giants like Goldman Sachs and Bank of America are trading at well below the valuation of other large companies, but even bargain hunters are wary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Scanlon is tempted by bank stocks, truly he is.

articles.headline: A Force Behind Lady Gaga Inc.
articles.snippet: The performer’s manager, a driving force behind her digital strategy, has helped create a start-up Web network, Backplane, and Lady Gaga is heavily invested.
articles.abstract: The performer’s manager, a driving force behind her digital strategy, has helped create a start-up Web network, Backplane, and Lady Gaga is heavily invested.
articles.lead_paragraph: Troy Carter, Lady Gaga’s manager, helped start Backplane, a way to connect fans, whether of music or sports teams.

articles.headline: Texas Still Has Its Rustlers, and Men in White Hats Chasing Them
articles.snippet: When cattle started disappearing from sale barns in various parts of Texas, disrupting the auction business, ranchers figured the thief wasn’t just grabbing at random.
articles.abstract: When cattle started disappearing from sale barns in various parts of Texas, disrupting the auction business, ranchers figured the thief wasn’t just grabbing at random.
articles.lead_paragraph: GROESBECK, Tex. — Whoever was stealing cattle had to have some cowboy in him, the theory went. You could tell by the seamless way he could lure more than a dozen animals at a time out of their pens, onto his trailer and into the endless Texas night, like some Pied Piper of bovines.

articles.headline: U.S. Braces for Withdrawal Along Iraqi Road
articles.snippet: American commanders say troops could be easy targets for insurgents as they depart along a 160-mile stretch.
articles.abstract: American commanders say troops could be easy targets for insurgents as they depart along a 160-mile stretch.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Even as the American military winds down its eight-year war in Iraq, commanders are bracing for what they fear could be the most dangerous remaining mission: getting the last troops out safely.

articles.headline: Antiwar Republican Is No Longer Party’s Pariah
articles.snippet: Representative Walter B. Jones is finding support in his party as an advocate for swift withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Representative Walter B. Jones is finding support in his party as an advocate for swift withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, N.C. — On matters like abortion, military spending and religion, Representative Walter B. Jones seems thoroughly in tune with this conservative, staunchly Republican district in eastern North Carolina, home to the Marine Corps’ Camp Lejeune and thousands of military retirees.

articles.headline: Frustration Grows as Nominee for the Fed Withdraws
articles.snippet: The decision by Peter A. Diamond to withdraw is raising concerns among some Democrats about the administration’s fighting spirit.
articles.abstract: The decision by Peter A. Diamond to withdraw is raising concerns among some Democrats about the administration’s fighting spirit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The decision by a noted economist Monday to end a 14-month wait for a seat on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors is renewing concerns among some Democrats about the fighting spirit of the Obama administration.
